title: How to master recruiting | Mads Faurholt-Jorgensen | TEDxWarwick
author: TEDx Talks

key_facts: Benjamin Sander is the conductor of the Boston Philharmonic Orchestra.
The Boston Philharmonic Orchestra is one of the best orchestras in the world.
Benjamin Sander is the only person in the orchestra without a sound.
Leadership is primarily about setting the right team for an organization.
The speaker considers himself a recruiter rather than a CEO or entrepreneur.
The speaker co-founded over 20 companies with highly skilled individuals.
No university courses are commonly available on selecting the right people for teams.
The US Department of Labor states that the cost of a bad hire is 30% of the role's salary.
McKinsey found a 67% productivity difference between top and bottom performers.
Hiring the wrong person negatively impacts team culture and individual happiness.
A common saying is that people spend 10% of their time recruiting and 90% fixing mistakes.
The speaker’s team developed a structured recruitment framework to improve hiring.
The speaker admits his personal talent in understanding people ranks lowest among his abilities.
The team uses an algorithm to predict a candidate’s success in a role.
The algorithm calculates a percentage chance of success based on predefined criteria.
key_opinions: Leadership is most important when it comes to building the right team.
Most leaders are not taught how to select people effectively.
People often hire others who are like themselves, which limits diversity.
It’s better to hire people smarter than yourself than to be the smartest person in the room.
Trying to hire someone who can do everything leads to poor team composition.
Hiring people worse than oneself undermines team performance and growth.
Quick decisions in interviews often confirm existing biases rather than assess merit.
Teams should be built around complementary roles, not identical skills.
Resumes alone are insufficient for identifying truly capable candidates.
Candidates with non-traditional backgrounds may possess valuable 'whispering talents'.
Culture fit is binary: if a candidate doesn’t fit, they won’t succeed regardless of skill.
Interviewers often misinterpret responses due to cognitive bias.
The best way to test a candidate is to have them perform the actual job for a few days.
Keeping detailed notes after hiring helps improve future decision-making.
Improving recruitment ability requires consistent reflection and iteration.
key_datapoints: The cost of a bad hire is 30% of the role’s annual salary.
Top performers are 67% more productive than bottom performers.
The speaker has co-founded over 20 companies.
The speaker’s ability to understand people ranks as the lowest among his talents.
The team leverages only 10% of the knowledge they believe they have about hiring.
The algorithm predicts a candidate’s success with a calculated percentage chance.
95% of positions evaluated use the brain-heart-toolbox model.
Candidates are tested through job simulations lasting 1–7 days.
Interviews typically last 45–50 minutes despite early judgments made in seconds.
The speaker’s team uses tools to evaluate candidates beyond resumes.
The team aims to spend 10% of time on recruitment and 90% on other activities.
The speaker’s team uses a three-part framework: needs, questions/tools, interpretation.
Only 10% of the team’s input comes from automated systems; 90% is human-driven.
The speaker’s personal experience includes being fired from McDonald’s.
The speaker was frequently sent to the principal’s office during high school.
